original_data.question: A 45-year-old G3P3 presents complaining of the feeling of a foreign body in her vagina that worsens on standing. She does not have urinary or fecal incontinence or any other genitourinary symptoms. She has no known gynecologic diseases. There were no complications with her pregnancies, all of which were full-term vaginal deliveries. She is sexually active with her husband and no longer uses oral contraceptives. She has an 11 pack-year history of smoking. Her weight is 79 kg (174 lb) and her height is 155 cm (5 ft). Her vital signs are within normal limits. The physical examination is unremarkable. The gynecologic examination reveals descent of the cervix halfway towards the introitus. On Valsalva and standing, the cervix descents to the plane of the hymen. The uterus is not enlarged and the ovaries are non-palpable. Which of the following treatments is most reasonable to offer this patient?

model_response:
This patient has a cystocele, cystourethrocele, and uterine prolapse. The cystocele and cystourethrocele are causing the feeling of a foreign body in the vagina. The uterine prolapse is classified as 2nd degree since the cervix descends halfway towards the introitus on Valsalva and standing. The treatment of choice for this patient is a sacral colpopexy. This procedure involves the attachment of the vaginal apex to the anterior longitudinal ligament of the sacrum. The success rate for this procedure is greater than 90% and the complication rate is less than 10%. A space-filling pessary may be offered to this patient as a temporary measure while she is waiting for surgery. A space-filling pessary will likely be unacceptable to her since it will remind her of the foreign body sensation. A postoperative pessary may be used after a sacral colpopexy. A posterior colporrhaphy is not indicated in this patient since her cervix is not enlarged. A pubocervical fascia repair is not indicated since her cervix does not descend beyond the hymen on Valsalva or when standing.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Emotional sensations.
Inanimate objects that become enclosed in the body.
The genital canal in the female, extending from the UTERUS to the VULVA. (Stedman, 25th ed)
The act of assuming or maintaining an erect upright position.
The duct which coveys URINE from the pelvis of the KIDNEY through the URETERS, BLADDER, and URETHRA.
Failure of voluntary control of the anal sphincters, with involuntary passage of feces and flatus.
Pathological processes involving the female reproductive tract (GENITALIA, FEMALE).
Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
A response indicating that an individual is or was sexually active.
A male partner in marriage.
The oval-shaped oral cavity located at the apex of the digestive tract and consisting of two parts: the vestibule and the oral cavity proper.
Chemical substances that prevent or reduce the probability of CONCEPTION.
The history of when and what an individual smoke(s) or smoked.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
The vertical measurement or distance from the base to the top of an object; the vertical dimension of extension.
Actions performed to measure temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Inspection and PALPATATION of female breasts, abdomen, and GENITALIA, as well as obtaining a gynecological history. (from Dictionary of Obstetrics and Gynecology)
The act of assuming or maintaining an erect upright position.
The neck portion of the UTERUS between the lower isthmus and the VAGINA forming the cervical canal.
Someone deriving or descending from an ancestor.
An imaginary surface formed by extension of a point through any axis or two definite points; any flat two-dimensional surface.
A thin fold of MUCOUS MEMBRANE situated at the orifice of the vagina.

The hollow thick-walled muscular organ in the female PELVIS. It consists of the fundus which is the site of EMBRYO IMPLANTATION and FETAL DEVELOPMENT. Beyond the isthmus at the perineal end of fundus, is CERVIX UTERI (the neck) opening into VAGINA. Beyond the isthmi at the upper abdominal end of fundus, are the FALLOPIAN TUBES.

The reproductive organ (GONADS) in female animals. In vertebrates, the ovary contains two functional parts: the OVARIAN FOLLICLE for the production of female germ cells (OOGENESIS); and the endocrine cells (GRANULOSA CELLS; THECA CELLS; and LUTEAL CELLS) for the production of ESTROGENS and PROGESTERONE.
Incapable of being handled, touched or felt through palpation.
Procedures concerned with the remedial treatment or prevention of diseases.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
